questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.

You have the devices shown in the following table.

//IMG//


Which devices can be changed to Windows 11 Enterprise by using subscription activation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Read the note that states. Note
Subscription activation is available for qualifying devices running Windows 10 or Windows 11. You can't use subscription activation to upgrade from Windows 10 to Windows 11.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation

Selected Answer: B
Subscription activation for Enterprise
Windows Enterprise E3 and E5 are available as online services via subscription. Windows Enterprise can be deployed in an organization without keys and reboots.
Devices with a current Windows Pro edition license can be seamlessly upgraded to Windows Enterprise.
Product key-based Windows Enterprise software licenses can be transitioned to Windows Enterprise subscription

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-subscription-activation?pivots=windows-11
Only device 3

If you came this far and still are unaware that Subscription does NOT upgrade your device from Windows 10 to 11, your failure on the exam is deserved. ;)

Answer is B.

Selected Answer: B
The Windows Enterprise subscription will not magically upgrade Windows 10 to 11. It only upgrades Windows Pro to Enterprise. So correct answer is Device 2 and 3. Device 1 won't be changed to Windows 11 Enterprise, rather Windows 10 Enterprise.
Wouldn't this be A? since device3 is the only one with subscription?
For all those saying you can't upgrade Win 10 Pro to 11 Pro with Windows Subscription Activation. You can. You'll only be prompted to upgrade if the Installation is not Windows 10 Pro.

comments.content: The question though is asking to upgrade devices to 11 enterprise with subscription activation, not pro to pro.

comments.content:
Windows 10 Pro for Workstation (Device 1): This edition cannot be directly upgraded to Windows 11 Enterprise via subscription activation. It needs to be upgraded to a standard Windows 10/11 Pro first.

Windows 11 Pro (Device 2): This device is activated with a key. It needs to be converted to subscription activation before it can be upgraded to Windows 11 Enterprise.

Windows 11 Pro (Device 3): This device is already activated with a subscription. This means it already has the necessary licensing to potentially upgrade to Windows 11 Enterprise.

Therefore, the correct answer is A. Device3 only. Important Note: While Device 3 is the only one that can be directly upgraded using subscription activation, it's worth noting that the upgrade itself might require further steps or configuration within Intune.
subscription activation does not upgrade the OS magically from Windows 10 to Windows 11.
you have explained nothing
I think from Windows 10 Pro you can use to upgrade to Windows 11 Pro and from there to Windows 11 Enterprise

Subscription activation for Enterprise
Windows Enterprise E3 and E5 are available as online services via subscription. You can deploy Windows Enterprise in your organization without keys and reboots.

Devices with a current Windows Pro edition license can be seamlessly upgraded to Windows Enterprise.
Product key-based Windows Enterprise software licenses can be transitioned to Windows Enterprise subscriptions.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/deployment/windows-10-subscription-activation

A user with “Deny logon locally” permissions can still connect via Remote Desktop Services, as these are two separate permissions.
On the other hand, the “Deny logon through Remote Desktop Services” policy determines which users are prevented from logging on to the device through a Remote Desktop connection. This means that the user cannot log in remotely via Remote Desktop Services.

Doesnt that mean deny local logins only.
But Allow Remote logins.
Yes, but he is also a member of the Administrator group which has access.

questions.question_text:
You have two computers named Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows 10. Computer2 has Remote Desktop enabled.

From Computer1, you connect to Computer2 by using Remote Desktop Connection.

You need to ensure that you can access the local drives on Computer1 from within the Remote Desktop session.

What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Seems to be correct. 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/block-legacy-authentication

Selected Answer: E
Here's a step-by-step guide:

Go to the Microsoft 365 admin center.

Navigate to "Security" and then "Conditional Access."

Create a new Conditional Access policy (CAPolicy1) and configure the following:

Assignments:

Users or workload identities: User1
Cloud apps or actions:

Include App1
Conditions:

Client apps: Modern authentication clients
Access controls:

Grant: Block access

Selected Answer: E
This is the correct page to use to self-verify that E is correct:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/policy-block-legacy-authentication

Selected Answer: E
To block only legacy authentication requests to App1, you need to target the type of client application used in the authentication request. In Conditional Access policies, this is done using the "Client apps" condition.

Therefore, the correct condition to add to CAPolicy1 is:

E. Client apps

Selected Answer: E
E is correct.

Selected Answer: E
E is correct

7. Under Conditions > Client apps, set Configure to Yes
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/howto-conditional-access-policy-block-legacy

E 
client apps https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/conditional-access/howto-conditional-access-policy-block-legacy

Selected Answer: E
Grant: Block access -
client Apps block only legacy authentication

E
Sign in to the Microsoft Entra admin center as at least a Conditional Access Administrator.
Browse to Protection > Conditional Access.
Select Create new policy.
Give your policy a name. We recommend that organizations create a meaningful standard for the names of their policies.
Under Assignments, select Users or workload identities.
Under Include, select All users.
Under Exclude, select Users and groups and choose any accounts that must maintain the ability to use legacy authentication. Exclude at least one account to prevent yourself from being locked out. If you don't exclude any account, you won't be able to create this policy.
Under Target resources > Cloud apps > Include, select All cloud apps.
Under Conditions > Client apps, set Configure to Yes.
Check only the boxes Exchange ActiveSync clients and Other clients.
Select Done.
Under Access controls > Grant, select Block access.

Selected Answer: E
Correct
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/conditional-access/howto-conditional-access-policy-block-legacy
Correct

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that contains a user named User1 and a web app named App1.
App1 must only accept modern authentication requests.
You plan to create a Conditional Access policy named CAPolicy1 that will have the following settings:

Assignments -
Users or workload identities: User1

Cloud apps or actions: App1 -

Access controls -

Grant: Block access -
You need to block only legacy authentication requests to App1.
Which condition should you add to CAPolicy1?

comments.content: "Each correct answer presents a complete solution", not "All 3 steps are required for a full solution".

discussion.content:
A, D, E.

Install Windows 11 Enterprise on each device:
 Subscription activation
Install a Windows Installer (MSI) package named App1 on each device:
 Provisioning packages
Add a certificate named Certificate1 that is required by App1:
 Provisioning packages
Join each device to Azure AD:
 Autopilot

Answer is correct. Pay attention to "Each correct answer presents a complete solution.". So ALL requirements must be filled by every single selection of solution.
a) subscription: upgrade only, nothing else
b) Custom image: yes, can do
c) In-place upgrade: upgrade only
d) Autopilot: yes
e) provisioning packages: yes
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/configuration/provisioning-packages/provisioning-packages

comments.content:
Should be ADE.
The purpose of Autopilot is to not require Custom Images so the answer would include both B and D together

As I wrote: subscription activation does nothing with the app and certificate requirements. In custom image you can have the app and the certificate "built-in", also a task to join to AD. In Autopilot, if you do not have any device/app configs assigned to the devices, it just resets the OS, so the fully correct option there would be Autopilot + Intune/SCCM/GPO
Not true. When you have deployed the Windows 11 Pro with Autopilot, it will receive the subscription activation, which upgrades the device to Enterprise.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDE
D - Installs Windows 11 Ent., Deploy MSI package via Intune, Install Certificate through Configuration Profile, Join to Azure AD during provisioning process.
E - Created with Windows Configuration Designer, Upgrades the OS to Win 11 Ent., Installs MSI Package, Add Certificate, Join devices to Azure AD
B - Preinstall Win 11 Ent and App1 in custom image included with Certificate in the image, and we can configure devices to join Azure AD during deployment.

Selected Answer: BDE
BDE because of "Each correct answer presents a complete solution"

b) Custom image: yes

e) provisioning packages: yes

custom image wont join to AD

Selected Answer: BDE
BDE confirmed by ChatGPT :)

Selected Answer: BDE
"Each correct answer presents a complete solution." THIS IS A REQUIREMENT

Subscription Activation cannot perform any other action apart from switching Pro to Enterprise. 
So Autopilot, custom image, and provisioning packages.

B,D,E 

Chatgpt:

D. Windows Autopilot

Windows Autopilot can be used to automatically join devices to Azure AD, upgrade Windows 11 Pro to Windows 11 Enterprise (through subscription activation), install required applications, and configure certificates.
E. provisioning packages

Provisioning packages can be used to configure devices for corporate use, including installing applications, configuring certificates, and joining devices to Azure AD.
B. a custom Windows image

A custom Windows image can include Windows 11 Enterprise, the MSI package (App1), and the certificate (Certificate1). After deployment, the devices can be joined to Azure AD.

B. a custom Windows image: You can create a custom Windows 11 Enterprise image that includes the required MSI package (App1) and the Certificate1, and then use this custom image to install Windows 11 Enterprise on each device.

D. Windows Autopilot: You can use Windows Autopilot to automate the deployment and configuration of new devices, including installing Windows 11 Enterprise, installing the MSI package (App1) as part of the Autopilot deployment profile, adding Certificate1, and joining the devices to Azure AD.

E. provisioning packages: You can create provisioning packages that include the installation of Windows 11 Enterprise, the installation of the MSI package (App1), adding Certificate1, and joining the devices to Azure AD. These provisioning packages can then be applied to each device during the initial setup process.

comments.content: This doesn't make sense, your justification for B is that you use an image with the MSI installed and the certificate. In E you are going to use a provisioning package to install an MSI and a certificate that is already installed via the custom image. That has to be wrong

discussion.content:

Provided answer is correct. Inplace upgrade and subscription activation doesn't magicaly join the device in Entra ID.

Selected Answer: BDE
Agreed

ChatGPT: To prepare the Windows 11 Pro devices for corporate use with the provided requirements, you can use the following provisioning options:

B. A custom Windows image: This allows you to install Windows 11 Enterprise on each device.

D. Windows Autopilot: This allows you to join each device to Azure AD and customize the device setup, including the installation of applications and certificates.

E. Provisioning packages: You can create a provisioning package that includes the installation of the MSI package named App1 and the addition of the required certificate named Certificate1.

So, the correct selections are B, D, and E.
Correct

While subscription activation may be part of the setup process, it doesn't directly address the other requirements, such as installing Windows 11 Enterprise, App1, and Certificate1.

In-place upgrades are typically used for updating or upgrading the existing operating system on a device. They do not address the initial provisioning requirements of installing a new OS and software.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune.

You have five new Windows 11 Pro devices.

You need to prepare the devices for corporate use. The solution must meet the following requirements:
• Install Windows 11 Enterprise on each device.
• Install a Windows Installer (MSI) package named App1 on each device.
• Add a certificate named Certificate1 that is required by App1.
• Join each device to Azure AD.

Which three provisioning options can you use? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
